author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Betsy Byars, Who Wrote of Deserted Children, Is Dead at 91
description: Ms. Byars’s award-winning children’s books, including “The Summer of the Swans” and “The Night Swimmers,” often dealt with abandonment.
content: Betsy Byars, who drew from life to write award-winning children’s books that often portrayed young people grappling with abandonment, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Seneca, S.C. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: C.D.C. Gives New Guidelines, New York to Close Restaurants and Schools and Italian Deaths Rise
description: The Federal Reserve cuts rates. The pandemic dominates the Democratic debate. And Germany imposes border restrictions.
content: [This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates on the coronavirus epidemic here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: A Gay Man Remembers His Awakening, as AIDS Shook His World
description: Paul Lisicky, author of “Later: My Life at the Edge of the World,” talks about Provincetown, the challenges of memoir and learning not to suppress anger.
content: The memoirist and novelist Paul Lisicky says that “versions” of his experiences in Provincetown, Mass. — the Cape Cod community renowned as an art colony and a thriving home for the L.G.B.T.Q. community — have appeared in his previous work. But his new book, “Later: My Life at the Edge of the World,” intimately and extensively recounts the time he spent there in the early 1990s, growing into his own, sexually and emotionally, in a community grappling with the AIDS epidemic. On one page, Lisicky remembers wondering: “How will I ever be able to leave this haven, so far from the repression and punishments of adulthood? Am I trapped in sweetness now?” And soon after, he’s describing the men who had come to Provincetown to live out their last days. “A retirement community,” he calls the town. “Say, Sun City, Ariz., but for young men in their 20s and 30s.” Below, Lisicky talks about the project’s false starts, learning not to suppress anger, his longtime love of Joni Mitchell’s music and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew M. Cuomo
title: Andrew Cuomo to President Trump: Mobilize the Military to Help Fight Coronavirus
description: The time is growing short and fewer options are available. Using federal troops to help create hospital beds is one we should try.
content: Dear Mr. President,
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Pro-Biden Republican
description: A reader says the Never Trumpers need to make sure that Joe Biden is the Democratic nominee. Also: Advice for choosing a running mate; keeping track of children.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Don’t Rush to Dismiss Medicare for All
description: Readers, American and Canadian, take issue with an Op-Ed article.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Schools, Restaurants and Bars Are Shut Down
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said that it was a wrenching decision to close places that are the “heart and soul of the city.”
content: Facing mounting pressure, New York City officials announced on Sunday a sweeping shutdown of tens of thousands of bars and restaurants, and the closure of the city’s public school system — the largest in the nation — in an effort to suppress the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Aimee Ortiz
title: Coronavirus Travel Restrictions, Across the Globe
description: Nations across the world have imposed travel restrictions to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Here, the current list of countries limiting entry.
content: Countries across the world have imposed travel restrictions to curb the spread of the coronavirus. This list, pulled from official government reports and the United States State Department, will be updated as new measures are announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
title: Biden, Courting Liberals, Backs Tuition-Free College for Some Students
description: In another overture to the Democratic Party’s left wing, Mr. Biden embraced a version of an idea championed by Senator Bernie Sanders, his chief rival for the Democratic nomination.
content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr., seeking to shore up support among progressive voters, now backs making public colleges and universities tuition-free for many students, adopting a version of a plan Senator Bernie Sanders has championed, his campaign announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: The Last Picture Show? Moviegoers Cautiously Take a Seat
description: Whether out of habit or to get out of the house, patrons around the country found they had little company in theaters. But for some, that was the whole point.
content: They were told not to go to their schools or offices. Concerns about long lines and shortages had discouraged them from going shopping. They could not visit libraries or museums; no concerts or shows were being held. There were no sporting events on TV, and only so many times that they could watch “Love Is Blind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder and Elian Peltier
title: Spain, on Lockdown, Weighs Liberties Against Containing Coronavirus
description: Empty streets. Shuttered stores. Spain has joined the number of countries struggling to balance public health with freedoms especially prized in a relatively young democracy.
content: MADRID — The scene is becoming all too familiar, and now it has gripped Spain: Streets are empty, shops are shuttered, families are cloistered at home and the numbers of those infected with the coronavirus, and those who have died, are growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Betsy Byars, Who Wrote of Deserted Children, Is Dead at 91
description: Ms. Byars’s award-winning children’s books, including “The Summer of the Swans” and “The Night Swimmers,” often dealt with abandonment.
content: Betsy Byars, who drew from life to write award-winning children’s books that often portrayed young people grappling with abandonment, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Seneca, S.C. She was 91.

content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr., seeking to shore up support among progressive voters, now backs making public colleges and universities tuition-free for many students, adopting a version of a plan Senator Bernie Sanders has championed, his campaign announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: ‘Here I Can Be My Own Dictator’
description: The Kremlin’s plan to hand out plots of land in Russia’s Far East, long a magnet for dissenters, idealists and oddballs, has attracted some unusually freethinking settlers.
content: NOVINKA, Russia — An outspoken critic of Russia’s current president, and of all the Kremlin leaders who came before, Sergei Lunin is an inveterate malcontent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Last Picture Show? Moviegoers Cautiously Take a Seat
description: Whether out of habit or to get out of the house, patrons around the country found they had little company in theaters. But for some, that was the whole point.

author: By Max Fisher and Emma Bubola
title: As Coronavirus Deepens Inequality, Inequality Worsens Its Spread
description: The pandemic is widening social and economic divisions that also make the virus deadlier, a self-reinforcing cycle that experts warn could have consequences for years to come.
content: As the coronavirus spreads across the globe, it appears to be setting off a devastating feedback loop with another of the gravest forces of our time: economic inequality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Pro-Biden Republican
description: A reader says the Never Trumpers need to make sure that Joe Biden is the Democratic nominee. Also: Advice for choosing a running mate; keeping track of children.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Margaret Shulman
title: How to Make College Decisions When Campuses Are Closed
description: With coronavirus closings, tours for admitted students are off the table. Here are some workarounds in this time of social distancing.
content: As colleges and universities nationwide shift to online classes in an attempt to curtail the spread of the coronavirus, the usual spring break college tours have been upended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: A Lockdown, Paris-Style: ‘We Can’t Live Without Bread’
description: Cafes and restaurants were closed, but it was no coincidence that food markets were open. Voters also cast ballots in an election seen as a referendum on the government.
content: PARIS — Parisians took the French government’s partial lockdown measures in stride on Sunday, half shrugging off the coronavirus threat and only limiting their normal weekend’s activities: shopping at open-air markets, strolling in parks and lining up outside bakeries and butchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: A Warm Welcome
description: Gary Cee ushers us into a new week with a frothy (but substantial) Monday puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is going to be a wonderful week to eat cake and solve puzzles, everybody. I thought that today’s grid was kind of tough for a Monday, mainly because of two little spots that seemed quite devious, intended to sow confusion. In addition, the theme didn’t immediately clonk me on the head. This is all grist for the mill, though, and how we get better at solving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise, Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Her Cancer Surgery Was Canceled at a Hospital Bracing for Coronavirus
description: Hospitals in hot spots like Seattle and New York are postponing elective surgeries, hoping to conserve resources as the outbreak escalates. More serious surgeries are also getting a second look.
content: SEATTLE — Alison Krupnick was mentally preparing herself for the surgery set for early in the coming week that could eliminate her early-stage cervical cancer. But on Friday, she got word from the hospital: Because of the crush of coronavirus patients, her surgery was being called off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Trump Oversold a Google Site to Fight Coronavirus
description: After Jared Kushner liked the idea, President Trump inflated the concept. The disconnect is the latest example of the president exaggerating or making wholly inaccurate statements about his administration’s response.
content: WASHINGTON — It started as a series of conversations this past week between officials working with Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law, and the chief executive of Verily, a life sciences subsidiary of Google’s parent company, about how it might help the Trump administration in the fight against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder and Elian Peltier
title: Spain, on Lockdown, Weighs Liberties Against Containing Coronavirus
description: Empty streets. Shuttered stores. Spain has joined the number of countries struggling to balance public health with freedoms especially prized in a relatively young democracy.
content: MADRID — The scene is becoming all too familiar, and now it has gripped Spain: Streets are empty, shops are shuttered, families are cloistered at home and the numbers of those infected with the coronavirus, and those who have died, are growing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Karen Dubbin, Reed Goodwin
description: The couple met three years ago on Craigslist.
content: Karen Ruth Dubbin and Reed Alexander Goodwin were married March 14 at the Palms Hotel & Spa in Miami Beach. Eric Dubbin, a Universal Life minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Julia Pucci, Matthew Dudley
description: The couple met four years ago in the Romance Language Lounge at Yale.
content: Julia Claire Pucci and Matthew Christopher Dudley were married March 14 at the home of the bride’s parents in Water Mill, N.Y. Rabbi Laurie Gold officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Heather Brennan, James Dennin
description: The couple met at Kenyon College, from which each graduated.
content: Heather Penelope Brennan and James Frederick Dennin were married March 14 at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York. The Rev. Canon Steven Lee, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sherilyn Notte, Jason Tuthill
description: The couple met in 2017 at a ski lodge in Stratton, Vt.
content: Sherilyn Michele Notte and Jason Brown Tuthill were married March 14 at the First Reformed Church of Pompton Plains in Pompton Plains, N.J. Pastor Dave Gustavsen, who was ordained by the Dallas Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Tempted to Bail Out? Alternatives Have Perils, Too
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 15, 2020.
content: “I can ask what you would feel if stocks went down 50 percent, but I’d have to kick you in the gut three times to simulate the pain you would actually feel.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Car That Was Turning Slowed Down, and the Window Rolled Down’
description: Wearing a favorite dress, a Manhattan wedding and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden, Looking to Attract Progressives, Endorses Warren Bankruptcy Plan
description: The two clashed over bankruptcy policy more than a decade ago. But Joseph R. Biden Jr. now supports Elizabeth Warren’s plan that allows student debt to be relieved in bankruptcy.
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has battled with Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts in the past over the issue of bankruptcy, now supports a plan by Ms. Warren to make changes to the bankruptcy system, his presidential campaign confirmed on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: It’ll Get Worse Before It Gets Better
description: The coronavirus is getting scarier, but try not to panic. The stock market is doing that for you.
content: Hello from my apartment, where I plan to remain for as long as my pretzel and coffee supply holds out. Here’s what you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech news (basically all coronavirus-related, of course). Stay safe and sane out there, everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: College in the Coronavirus Era: Wistful Goodbyes and a Sense of Loss
description: “I feel like a lot of experiences have been stolen from me,” said one Cornell University senior, as students left campus.
content: ITHACA, N.Y. — When Cornell University administrators emailed students last week, sobs were heard in libraries and labs. People wiped tears from friends’ faces — then slathered on hand sanitizer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: This Tom Hanks Story Will Make You Feel Less Bad
description: On this special episode, Times features writer Taffy Brodesser-Akner learns just how nice Tom Hanks really is.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and David Scull
title: Coronavirus, 2020 Debate, Tigers: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: Suffering Through Your First Financial Crisis? Read This to Relax
description: We’ve been here before, and everything will be fine.
content: You already know the rational steps to take during a financial crisis: Don’t look at your 401(k) or investment accounts. Don’t stay glued to CNBC or the financial press. And, above all else, do not panic-sell your investments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: What Bernie Sanders’s Allies Want to Hear at Tonight’s Debate
description: Progressives hope Mr. Sanders will push Joe Biden on the issues they care about most, and they realize that anything resembling a personal attack may seem off-putting amid the coronavirus crisis.
content: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, the onetime Democratic presidential front-runner who notched victories in several early states, is now facing long odds. It’s not impossible — though it is statistically unlikely — for him to reverse the course of the primary and mount a comeback against former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Maggie Astor
title: Biden vs. Sanders, Issue by Issue
description: Sunday’s debate will be the first one-on-one matchup between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Bernie Sanders. So, how do they actually compare on policy?
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will debate one on one for the first time on Sunday, and Mr. Sanders, who is staying in the Democratic primary race despite a series of defeats, has already telegraphed his strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Anderson and Nicholas Bagley
title: This Is One Anxiety We Should Eliminate for the Coronavirus Outbreak
description: A patient can do everything right and still face substantial surprise medical bills.
content: In his recent Oval Office speech, President Trump pledged that Americans won’t receive surprise bills for their coronavirus testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
title: New York Officials Weigh Delaying April Primary Election
description: Discussions to push back the state’s primary because of the coronavirus crisis came as several states that vote on Tuesday were cautiously moving ahead, and as Bernie Sanders voiced concerns.
content: New York officials are considering plans to postpone the state’s presidential primary election in April as fears over the coronavirus outbreak grow and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention cautioned against gatherings of more than 50 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: When Facebook Is More Trustworthy Than the President
description: Social media companies are delivering reliable information in the coronavirus crisis. Why can’t they do that all the time?
content: For some Americans, reality arrived Jan. 25, when a Harvard epidemiologist tweeted “HOLY MOTHER OF GOD.” Or on Feb. 29, when researchers announced they had found cases in Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Ahead of the Pack, How Microsoft Told Workers to Stay Home
description: Its executives, with headquarters just a few miles from one of the country’s worst coronavirus outbreaks, were among the first to confront the impact.
content: SEATTLE — Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, was at home, relaxing after a trip to India and Indonesia, when he started seeing news alerts on his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Weighs Tariff Relief but Some Fear China Will Take Advantage
description: Politicians and business groups are sharply divided on what to do about President Trump’s tariffs, with some arguing that China is poised to take advantage of the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus outbreak is prompting a heated debate among lawmakers and the White House over whether the Trump administration should remove the tariffs it has imposed on China and other nations to provide some economic relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Cornbread. Now, More Than Ever.
description: Comfort foods, and the old ways of making them, bring solace when you really need it.
content: NASHVILLE — The obsession started back in the fall, long before the coronavirus pandemic, when I bought a copy of Anne Byrn’s new cookbook, “Skillet Love,” to give to my brother-in-law, Harry, for Christmas. During his single years, Harry always spent the holidays with us, and he always made a happy fuss over my cornbread, which of course I make in a cast-iron skillet. (If you are making cornbread in anything other than a cast-iron skillet, stop right now.) Eventually Harry bought his own skillet and learned to make cornbread himself. Eventually, too, he remarried. I am not saying that good cornbread leads to marriage, but I’m not saying it doesn’t either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: A Deadly Lack of Leadership
description: The president congratulates himself.
content: This is what it looks like when a crisis of leadership makes its way into our health and our homes, when lack of prudence induces panic, when the president himself cannot be trusted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Markets Unsteady as Fed Signals Urgency of Economic Threat
description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates to near-zero and said it would buy up huge amounts of government and mortgage-backed debt in an effort backstop the United States economy.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Live coverage can be found here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery, David Yaffe-Bellany, Amelia Nierenberg and Quoctrung Bui
title: ‘There Is Plenty of Food in the Country’
description: Americans have been alarmed by empty grocery shelves, but while food suppliers and retailers say they are struggling with surging demand, they insist the supply chain remains strong.
content: The aisles and aisles of empty store shelves give the appearance that the United States, improbably and alarmingly, is running out of food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Farah Stockman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Airports Reel as New Coronavirus Screening Goes into Effect
description: Conditions improved Sunday, after travelers from Europe waited in lines as long as seven hours for screening on Saturday.
content: ATLANTA — After a night of chaos at some of the nation’s busiest airports on Saturday, officials scrambled on Sunday, with some apparent success, to reduce lines that had left people jammed together for hours as they waited for new health screenings mandated for travelers from Europe in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery, David Yaffe-Bellany, Amelia Nierenberg and Quoctrung Bui
title: ‘There Is Plenty of Food in the Country’
description: Americans have been alarmed by empty grocery shelves, but while food suppliers and retailers say they are struggling with surging demand, they insist the supply chain remains strong.
content: The aisles and aisles of empty store shelves give the appearance that the United States, improbably and alarmingly, is running out of food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Farah Stockman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Airports Reel as New Coronavirus Screening Goes into Effect
description: Conditions improved Sunday, after travelers from Europe waited in lines as long as seven hours for screening on Saturday.
content: ATLANTA — After a night of chaos at some of the nation’s busiest airports on Saturday, officials scrambled on Sunday, with some apparent success, to reduce lines that had left people jammed together for hours as they waited for new health screenings mandated for travelers from Europe in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Andrew Testa
title: Fishing Presents a Vexing Snag in Brexit Talks
description: Lacking in economic clout, the industry punches far above its weight in emotional power, presenting a tough barrier for negotiators.
content: BRIXHAM, England — In the pitch black of early morning, huge waves hurled the 30-ton vessel from side to side, drenching crewmen who struggled to keep their footing as they cast the trawler’s nets into the swirling seas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The V.A. Prepares to Back Up a Health Care System Threatened by Coronavirus
description: The sprawling Department of Veterans Affairs is legally designated as the nation’s backup health system and could prove vital in the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — The Department of Veterans Affairs, legally designated as the backup health care system in national emergencies, is preparing to absorb the overflow of coronavirus patients from private hospitals if — or when — they become strained to the breaking point. It would be the biggest test the sprawling and sometimes troubled government hospital system has faced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Quarantine Prepping Comes to the Farmers’ Market, Measuredly
description: In Santa Monica, Calif., shoppers at the downtown market found lots of daikon and little social distancing.
content: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Kong Thao considered the chaos of the coronavirus as a farmer. “We’re treating it like a winter,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make Alison Roman’s fine new recipe for a spicy pork noodle soup, and start on your preparations for St. Patrick’s Day.
content: Good morning. The ides of March are come, and some call the day bad luck, a warning to be careful, to check your six. Of course, it was a bad day for Julius Caesar — stabbed to death at a meeting of the Roman Senate on this day 44 years before the birth of Christ — but, for the rest of us, I’m hoping it’s the opposite, a chance to mark the coming spring, a chance to believe in the future. We ought to cook in any event, both for the joy of it and to prepare for the coming week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Eric Taylor, Poetic Texas Singer-Songwriter, Is Dead at 70
description: Revered by peers like Lyle Lovett, he fused a brooding yet tender melodicism with evocative stream-of-consciousness narration, to hypnotic effect.
content: Eric Taylor, a relatively unknown Texas singer-songwriter revered by his more celebrated peers for his painterly lyrics and dexterous finger-style guitar playing, died on March 9 in Austin. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Perri Birnbach, Nicholas Newburger
description: The couple met while on a flight en route to Coachella in Southern California.
content: Perri Lauren Birnbach and Nicholas Avery Newburger were married March 14 at the 1 Hotel South Beach in Miami Beach. Rabbi Steven Moskowitz officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amy Saul, Jason Mollengarden
description: During their first date they discovered they had family ties.
content: Amy Brooke Saul and Jason Lawrence Mollengarden were married March 14 at the Biltmore Ballrooms, an events space in Atlanta. J. Stephen Schuster, a judge on the Superior Court of Cobb County in Marietta, Ga., officiated, with Rabbi Samantha Trief taking part in the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: For Biden and Sanders, the Fight’s Not Personal
description: The amicable relationship the two have maintained could become an important factor in the Democrats’ ability to unite quickly against President Trump.
content: In October 2015, Senator Bernie Sanders was whisked into Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s residence at the Naval Observatory for a breakfast of yogurt parfaits and caffeinated campaign advice from a vice president who had just announced his (temporary) retirement from presidential politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla and Zach Montague
title: Nunes Encourages People to Dine Out as Experts Urge Them to Stay Home
description: Representative Devin Nunes, a California Republican, appealed to Americans to help promote the economy in the face of the coronavirus pandemic. Health experts are advocating isolation.
content: Representative Devin Nunes, a California Republican, on Sunday encouraged healthy people to dine out at restaurants, contradicting public health advisories that strongly encouraged social distancing and discouraged Americans from attending mass gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Eric Taylor, Poetic Texas Singer-Songwriter, Is Dead at 70
description: Revered by peers like Lyle Lovett, he fused a brooding yet tender melodicism with evocative stream-of-consciousness narration, to hypnotic effect.
content: Eric Taylor, a relatively unknown Texas singer-songwriter revered by his more celebrated peers for his painterly lyrics and dexterous finger-style guitar playing, died on March 9 in Austin. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: California Calls for Residents 65 and Older to Stay at Home
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom also said bars and wineries should close but restaurants could stay open if they cut their occupancy in half.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday called for what he called “profoundly significant steps” to limit the spread of coronavirus, including the isolation at home of all residents 65 years and older; the closure of nightclubs, wineries and bars; and the purchase by the state of hotels to shelter some of the state’s 150,000 homeless people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Leitch
title: How Will Sports Recover From This Hiatus?
description: Much of fandom is about continuity — knowing that games have always been going on and always will be. That changed last week.
content: If you were to pick a year in the past century or so and ask me to name something that happened then, my answer would almost certainly have to do with sports. Nineteen-seventy? Willis Reed hobbles back to help the New York Knicks win the N.B.A. Finals. Nineteen-twenty-seven? The Babe Ruth-Lou Gehrig New York Yankees, the greatest team of all time. Nineteen-eighty? “Do you believe in miracles?!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: New York City Public Schools to Close
description: Following days of pressure, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced plans to close the nation’s largest public school system.
content: New York City’s public school system, the nation’s largest, will begin shutting down this week, by far the most far-reaching and disruptive measure the city has taken yet to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmy Ayala and Patricia Mazzei
title: Puerto Rico Imposes Curfew, Shuts Businesses Over Coronavirus
description: In one of the most serious U.S. crackdowns yet over Covid-19, the governor ordered most businesses on the island to shut down. Other U.S. cities were imposing control measures of their own.
content: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Puerto Rico imposed a curfew on Sunday and ordered most businesses shut down, imposing some of the most widespread restrictions yet seen in the United States as a growing number of jurisdictions moved to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Public School Is a Child’s Right. Should Preschool Be Also?
description: Some Democrats, including Bernie Sanders, say the government-financed care and education of children should start at birth instead of at kindergarten.
content: In the United States, the chance that a child attends a high-quality preschool — which research has shown sets them on a more successful life path — often depends on whether the parents can afford it. But what if government-funded care and education of children started soon after birth?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Katie Glueck and Shane Goldmacher
title: Highlights From the March Democratic Debate
description: The debate between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders was hosted by CNN and Univision. It took place in Washington, D.C., because of concerns over the coronavirus.
content: The large field of Democrats is now down to only two major candidates: former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Because of concerns about the coronavirus, the debate was moved from Phoenix to Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Arizona Boom Draws Californians and Changes Political Hue
description: A decade after the recession hit hard, Arizona’s economy is a magnet for technology companies and for workers seeking an affordable middle-class life.
content: PHOENIX — Colin Jordan, a 32-year-old software salesman, lists various predictable reasons for his move to Scottsdale from the San Francisco Bay Area. He likes sun and golf and lower income taxes. But beneath all that is something bigger, which is the feeling that Arizona has welcomed him in ways that California — where he grew up — did not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Neil Irwin
title: Fed Slashes Rates to Near-Zero and Unveils Sweeping Program to Aid Economy
description: The central bank cut rates by a full percentage point and announced a giant bond-buying campaign to insulate the economy against coronavirus fallout.
content: WASHINGTON — With the fast-spreading coronavirus posing a dire threat to economic growth, the Federal Reserve on Sunday night took the dramatic step of slashing interest rates to near-zero and unveiled a sweeping set of programs in an effort backstop the United States economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman, Patricia Cohen, Stacy Cowley, Conor Dougherty, Nicholas Kulish, David McCabe and Karen Weise
title: Coronavirus Cost to Businesses and Workers: ‘It Has All Gone to Hell’
description: As the outbreak forces the cancellation of trips, nights out and large gatherings, economic damage is mounting across the country.
content: A week ago, Mark Canlis’s restaurant in Seattle was offering a $135 tasting menu to a bustling dining room every night. Eileen Hornor’s inn on the Maine coast was booking rooms for the busy spring graduation season. And Kalena Masching, a real estate agent in California, was fielding multiple offers on a $1.2 million home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
title: White House Seeks Financial Crisis-Era Powers to Buttress Economy
description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin says he’ll ask Congress to reinstate authorities that were scaled back by the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act.
content: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Sunday that he would ask Congress to reinstate powers that were used during the 2008 financial crisis to support the economy as the coronavirus threatens to grind business activity in the United States to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Benny Gantz, With Thin Majority, Wins Chance to Form Israeli Government
description: In a first, all 15 members of the combined slate of predominantly Arab parties joined lawmakers from Jewish parties in recommending Mr. Gantz over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
content: JERUSALEM — Benny Gantz, the centrist former army chief battling to depose Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, on Sunday won the endorsements of a narrow majority of lawmakers, earning him a fresh chance to form a government and break Israel’s yearlong political deadlock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Coronavirus, Remembering Christchurch, Israel Elections: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: For Danilo Gallinari, the N.B.A. Shutdown Wasn’t So Sudden
description: The coronavirus outbreak has been front and center for the Italian N.B.A. star for weeks through family and friends back home.
content: As Danilo Gallinari remembers it, he was the first player on the court Wednesday night at Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, eager for the jump ball that would start the game between Gallinari’s Thunder and the Utah Jazz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
title: The 2020 Campaign: Postponements and Cancellations Because of Coronavirus
description: Georgia and Louisiana delayed their primary elections, and Bernie Sanders questioned whether elections should be held right now. Here are the latest updates on changes to the 2020 presidential race.
content: As the coronavirus outbreak upends the presidential campaign, we’re keeping tabs on postponements and cancellations in the election calendar and on major changes for voting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Adam Goldman
title: Trump Says He’s ‘Strongly Considering’ Pardoning Flynn
description: Amid increasing anxiety over the coronavirus, the president said he expected to pardon Michael T. Flynn, his former national security adviser who had pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I.
content: WASHINGTON — As the country reeled from growing health and economic crises brought on by the spread of the coronavirus, President Trump announced on Sunday that he was “strongly considering” a pardon for his former national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Europeans Erect Borders Against Coronavirus, but the Enemy Is Already Within
description: In societies where life plays out on the street or in the cafe, where friends are greeted with kisses on the cheeks, the outbreak is creating fear and fragmentation.
content: BRUSSELS — The “gilded museum” of Europe is hollow and echoing. The great squares and stadiums are empty, the museums shut, the churches hesitant about services, the fine restaurants and cool bars shuttered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York City to Close Schools, Restaurants and Bars: Live Updates
description: The moves are the most far-reaching and disruptive the city has taken to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
content: New York City’s public school system, the nation’s largest with 1.1 million students, will begin to largely shut down this week, in what is the city’s most aggressive and disruptive effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Complete List of Trump’s Attempts to Play Down Coronavirus
description: He could have taken action. He didn’t.
content: President Trump made his first public comments about the coronavirus on Jan. 22, in a television interview from Davos with CNBC’s Joe Kernen. The first American case had been announced the day before, and Kernen asked Trump, “Are there worries about a pandemic at this point?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter, Raphael Minder, Elisabetta Povoledo and Steven Erlanger
title: Restrictions on Movement Grow as Governments Try to Slow Coronavirus
description: People around the world are increasingly being urged to stay home.
content: Faced with a virus that won’t slow down, the world itself moved Sunday to come to a near halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: ‘We Call for Calm’: Mexico’s Restrained Response to the Coronavirus
description: The López Obrador government’s measured approach to battling the coronavirus played out this weekend in a full soccer schedule and a crowded music festival. “Yes, there’s worry,” one fan said, “but you have to have fun.”
content: MEXICO CITY — Before she headed to the soccer game this weekend, Gabriela Gómez considered the matter of the coronavirus and its transmissibility in crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: The 2020 Campaign Is Over. The Coronavirus Campaign Just Started.
description: Politics is personal. So what happens when people can’t be near one another?
content: The candidates remained their essential selves — even at a virtual, epidemiology-minded distance — as if straying from their preferred political brands would amount to coronavirus surrender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Analysis of the Biden vs. Sanders Debate, March 15
description: We watched the Democratic presidential debate — a one-on-one matchup between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Bernie Sanders during the coronavirus pandemic — and analyzed it in real time.
content: We watched the Democratic presidential debate — a one-on-one matchup between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Bernie Sanders during the coronavirus pandemic — and analyzed it in real time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Players Vote Yes on New 10-Year Labor Deal
description: The vote paves the way for the addition of a 17th regular-season game, an expansion to the playoffs and increased minimum salaries.
content: N.F.L. players have approved a new 10-year labor deal that will include the first major expansion to the N.F.L. season in more than four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Think Cheating in Baseball Is Bad? Try Chess
description: Smartphones, buzzers, even yogurt — chess has nearly seen it all in both live and online tournaments. And just as in baseball, technology only makes it harder to root out.
content: Until the sports world ground to a halt last week over the coronavirus outbreak, perhaps the biggest issue looming over professional sports in the United States was the Houston Astros’ cheating scandal. The revelations of their scheme led Major League Baseball’s commissioner, Rob Manfred, to deliver a stern warning to all 30 club owners that there was a “culture of cheating” in the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry and Todd Heisler
title: ‘Everything Is a Black Hole’: Mounting Dread in the Age of Coronavirus
description: Isolation, uncertainty and confusion set in as the pandemic grips the United States.
content: In a Harlem cafe late last week, a woman reading her cellphone sneezed without covering her mouth. On an ordinary day, the fleeting moment would pass barely noticed. But these are not ordinary days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Movie Crowds Stay Away. Theaters Hope It’s Not for Good.
description: Cinemas, already contending with streaming services, are now facing the prospect of no audiences and no new films because of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: LOS ANGELES — For most of last week, movie theater executives clung grimly on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: ‘It’s Totally Ad Hoc’: Why America’s Virus Response Looks Like a Patchwork
description: For centuries, the United States has resisted a centralized public health policy. This week, as protective measures against the coronavirus varied county to county, Americans saw the cost.
content: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — David Norton, who helps to run a community center in this small Rhode Island city, is not a scientist. Neither were the board members who gathered for an emergency meeting last week, to decide whether the risk of contagion meant they should cancel their upcoming events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez, Kwame Opam and John Taggart
title: Coronavirus Has Already Muted One of N.Y.’s Rowdiest Night Life Areas
description: “The vibe is feeling like getting your last social interaction in,” said a co-owner of a cocktail bar on the Lower East Side.
content: The start of the weekend among the bars and clubs of Manhattan’s Lower East Side looked — and felt — more as if the end of one. Empty cabs rolled down darkened streets, past lonely food carts plopped on sidewalks where few pedestrians scurried by. Some venues closed, while others worried they might be next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Stirring Sermons About Coronavirus, in Empty Cathedrals
description: With large gatherings banned, ministers offered messages of calm and compassion on Sunday as parishioners watched on live stream.
content: At 11:15 on Sunday morning, the Rev. Kristin Kaulbach Miles, a priest at Trinity Church Wall Street, stepped into the sanctuary of the soaring 1846 Gothic Revival building in Manhattan and delivered a sermon about the need to come together in the face of coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ria Misra
title: 5 Ways to Help Your Community Combat Coronavirus (While Still Social Distancing)
description: Instead of isolating, you can help your neighbors and community in these ways.
content: The number of coronavirus cases in the United States is ticking steadily upward, and with it are Americans’ collective anxiety levels. But stockpiling massive caches of toilet paper and bottled water for insular forts will only lead to more shortages and more stress. Instead, the best way for us all to prepare is by looking out for one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 16, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Betty Gilpin Is Proud of ‘The Hunt,’ the Year’s Most Controversial Movie
description: It’s been an emotional roller coaster for the star: “I didn’t know if our movie was going to be put on lampsandtirescleaningservice.com.”
content: Before audiences got a chance to see it, “The Hunt” entered theaters on Friday as one of the most polarizing and notorious films of the year. The movie is a dark satire in which a group of conservatives are kidnapped and hunted for sport by sadistic liberals, and it was originally scheduled to be released by Universal last September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: How CNN Is Planning a Safe Debate (One Step: Six Feet Between the Lecterns)
description: Lots of hand sanitizer and a closed set are part of the cable network’s preparations for a debate between two septuagenarian Democrats.
content: They say political debating is a contact sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: A Sunday Without Church: In Crisis, a Nation Asks, ‘What Is Community?’
description: Canceled religious services are another symbol of a lost chance to be still, to breathe and to gather together.
content: COLUMBIA, MD. — It was Sunday morning, and the vast parking lots of Bridgeway Community Church sat empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio
title: The Workers Who Face the Greatest Coronavirus Risk
description: Nurses and doctors rank high. But so do hairdressers and dentists.
content: Nurses and doctors rank high. But so do hairdressers and dentists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Can It Happen Here? In ‘The Plot Against America,’ It Already Did
description: David Simon’s potent HBO adaptation of the Philip Roth novel imagines a country tilting toward fascism.
content: There’s a repeating motif in David Simon’s passionate, gutting adaptation of Philip Roth’s 2004 novel “The Plot Against America.” A Jewish boy in early 1940s Newark is sitting in his bedroom when he hears an airplane overhead. Maybe it’s a warplane. Maybe it’s the president. Neither is a comforting thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: The Man With 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer Just Donated Them
description: A Tennessee man had planned to sell his stockpile at marked-up prices online. Now he is under investigation for price gouging.
content: A Tennessee man who became a subject of national scorn after stockpiling 17,700 bottles of hand sanitizer donated all of the supplies on Sunday just as the Tennessee attorney general’s office began investigating him for price gouging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Movie Ticket Sales Fall to Historic Low
description: The coronavirus pandemic hurt new films like “Bloodshot” and “The Hunt.” But the faith-based “I Still Believe” found an audience.
content: LOS ANGELES — Here is all you need to know about the mind-sets of moviegoers as the coronavirus pandemic intensifies: God beat a superhero at the weekend box office.
source.name: The New York Times
